item.title: Notes on Behavioural Economics
item.description: Basic Ideas Standard Neoclassical Model Behavioural = Non-Standard Model Reference Dependence Endowment Effect Income Effect textbook 1: (DS) The foundations of behavioral economic analysis textbook 2: (WK) An introduction to behavioral economics Basic Ideas Standard Neoclassical Model Time index: \(t = 0, 1, 2,\dots\) Set of possible states: \(S_t\) Probability of \(s_t\) occurs: \(p(s_t)\) Set of consumption opportunities: \(X_t\) Utility function: \(U(x \ | \ s)\) Discounting factor: \(δ\) Agent’s problem: \(\max_{x_t} \ \sum_t δ^t( \sum_{s_t\in S_t} U(x_t \ | \ s_t)\cdot p(s_t))\) Behavioural = Non-Standard Preference: \(U\) and \(δ\) Reference dependence Loss aversion Time inconsistent Self-control problem (?

item.title: Notes on Institutions, Contract & Information
item.description: Literature Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Timing Benchmark Limited Liability Literature Contract Theory Game Theory (multi-stage games) Institutions and Economic Theory (very general and theoretical) Institutional Economics: An Introduction (Groenewegen, J. & Spithoven, A. & Van den Berg, A.) Firms, contracts, and financial structure (incomplete contract) Adverse Selection (Hidden Information) Lemon Market Moral Hazard (Hidden Action) Return: \(v\) Effort level: \(e\) Techonology: \(F(\hat{v} \ | \ e) = Pr(v\leq \hat{v} \ | \ e)\) Cost: \(c(e)\) Contract: \(t\) Principle’s payoff: \(v - t\) Agent’s payoff: \(t - c(e)\) Reservation utility: \(\underline{U} = 0\) Incentive compatility constraint (IC): agent chooses the level of effort that maximizes their own utility Participation constraint (PC): agent accepts the contract only if the expected utility exceeds other alternatives (their reservation utility) Timing Principal offers contract Agent accepts or rejects Agent chooses \(e\) (unobservable) \(v\) is realized (verifiable) Payment \(t\) is made Benchmark First best solution: \[\begin{aligned}e^{FB} &= \text{argmax} \ E[v \ | \ e] - c(e) \\ &= \begin{cases} p(e)\cdot v_H + \big( 1-p(e)\big) \cdot v_L & v\in\{ v_L, v_H\} \\ \int_{v_L}^{v_H} v\cdot f(v|e)dv & v\in [v_L, v_H]\end{cases}\end{aligned}\] where \(p(e) = Pr(v = v_H \ | \ e)\) Franchising contract: \(t(v) = v-a\) Agent’s problem \[\begin{aligned}\max_e && E[t(v) \ | \ e] - c(e) &= E[v \ | \ e] - a - c(e) \\ && e^* &= e^{FB} \end{aligned}\] Principle’s payoff \[\begin{aligned}v-t(v) &= a \\ &= E[v \ | \ e^{FB}] - c(e^{FB})\end{aligned}\] Limited Liability Return: \(v\in \{v_H, v_L\}\) Effort level: \(e\in \{ e_H, e_L\}\) Technology: \(\begin{cases}Pr( v = v_H \ | \ e = e_H ) = e_H \\ Pr( v = v_H \ | \ e=e_L ) = e_L \\ e_L < eH \end{cases}\) Cost: \(\begin{cases}c(e_H) = c \\ c(e_L) = 0 \end{cases}\) First best solution \(e^{FB} = e_H\) when \[\begin{aligned} e_H v_H - (1-e_H )v_L - c &\geq e_Lv_H + (1-e_L)v_L \\ (e_H - e_L)(v_H - v_L) &\geq c\end{aligned}\] \(e^{FB} = e_L\) otherwise Second best solution Contract: \(\begin{cases}t(v_H) = t_H \\ t(v_L) = t_L \end{cases}\) When principle wants to implement \(e = e_H\) \[\begin{aligned}\max && &e_H(v_H - t_H) + (1-e_H)(v_L - t_L) \\ (IC) && &e_H t_H - (1-e_H )t_L - c \geq e_L t_H - (1-e_L )t_L - 0 \\ (PC) && &e_H t_H - (1-e_H )t_L - c \geq \underline{U} = 0 \\ (LL) && &\begin{cases}t_H \geq 0 \\t_L \geq 0 \end{cases}\end{aligned}\] Lemma: \(\begin{cases}t_H = \frac{c}{e_H - e_L} \\ t_L = 0\end{cases}\) is a solution

item.title: Notes on Mechanism Design & Social Choice
item.description: Mechanism Design Problem Environment Mechanism Induced Game Social Choice Function & Implementation Textbook: (MWG) Microeconomic Theory Mechanism Design Problem Reference Environment Set of agents: \(i\in N = \{1,2,\dots, n\}\) Set of possible alternatives: \(x\in X\) \(x\) is single-valued (MWG Definition 21.E.1) Type profile: \(θ = (θ_1, θ_2,\dots, θ_n)\in Θ = Θ_1\times Θ_2\times\dots\times Θ_n\) pdf of \(θ\) over \(Θ\): \(f\) Agent \(i\)’s type: \(θ_i \in Θ_i\) Agent \(i\)’s vNM utility function: \(u_i(x,θ)\) Allow for selflessness Allow for reference Independent private values environment assumption Private value: \(u_i(x,θ) = u_i(x,θ_i)\) Independent type: \(f_i(θ_i)\) s.

item.title: Notes on Game Theory
item.description: Extensive Game, Perfect Information Strategy Subgame Chance Moves Bargaining textbook 1: (OR) A Course in Game Theory textbook 2: (BM) Fun and games Reference: Carlos Hurtado’s lecture notes Extensive Game, Perfect Information OR 6.1 Reference Set of players: \(N\) Set of histories: \(H\) History (sequence): \(h = (a^k)_{k=1}^K\) Initial history: \(\emptyset\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\), \(K>L\implies (a^k)_{k=1}^L\in H\) \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) for all \(K\in\mathbb{N} \implies (a^k)_{k=1}^{\infty}\in H\) Set of terminal histories: \(Z\) Terminal history: \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) is terminal if exists no \((a^k)_{k=1}^{K+1}\in H\) Set of (possible) actions: \(A(h): \{ a \ | \ (h,a)\in H\}\) Action: \(a\in h\) for some \(k\in K\) History of length \(k+1\): \((h,a)\) Player function: \(P: (H\backslash Z)\to N\) Player to move after history \(h\): \(P(h)\) Initial player: \(P(\emptyset)\) with \(a^0\in A(\emptyset)\) Second player: \(P(a^0)\) with \(a^1\in A(a^0)\) Preference relation: \(\succsim_i\) defined on \(Z\) Extensive Game with Perfect Information: \[Γ = \langle N,H,P,(\succsim_i)\rangle\text{ or }\langle N,H,P\rangle\] Finite game: \(|H|<\infty\) Finite horizon: \(K <\infty\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Rank of game: \(\max K\) for all \((a^k)_{k=1}^K\in H\) Length of game: \(l(Γ)\) is the length of longest history in \(Γ\) Exercise (slides P13)

item.title: Notes on Mathematics - Optimization and Dynamics
item.description: Optimization Lagrange Method Kuhn-Tucker Method Dual Problem Dynamics Recursive Analysis Finite Markov Chain Backward Induction Optimization Lagrange Method PS11.Q1 Solve \(\max_{(x,y)\in \mathbb{R}^2} x+y\) s.t. \(x^2+y^2=2\) Lagrangian: \[\mathcal{L}(x,y,λ) = x+y+λ(x^2+y^2-2)\] FOC \[\begin{aligned} \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial x} = 1 + 2λx = 0 && x &= -\frac{1}{2λ} \\ \frac{\partial\mathcal{L}}{\partial y} = 1 + 2λy = 0 && y &= -\frac{1}{2λ} \\ x^2+y^2=2 && \frac{1}{4λ^2} &= 1 \implies λ = \pm \frac{1}{2}\end{aligned}\] 1.

item.title: About
item.description: Last Update Me 饭 Hello. I’m loikein from China. I live in Bonn, Germany for my graduate study in economics. During undergraduate study in Japan, I majored in economics and minored in computer science. I speak Chinese (native), Japanese (near native) and English (academic proficient). Feel free to point out any mistakes or compliment my aesthetic talent. Dependencies Icon created with Dotgrid Avatar created with CHARAT YOCO Theme: jrutheiser/hugo-lithium-theme, modified by Yihui and me

item.title: Rmd Template
item.description: Words of Warning Rmd Reference Reference Cheatsheet Inline Code Executed Display Code R Code Chunk R Code (Inline) Code from Other Languages LaTeX Reference Image Reference Plot Words of Warning I use Typora to write my posts. Its WYSIWYG mode usually processes .Rmd file correctly, but gets lost in a file as complicated as this one. Always check twice and preview the .html page.
